chapter: Pituitary Tumours and Sheehan s Syndrome

questions.question: Question 1: What is the most common functioning tumor of the pituitary?
questions.explanation:
Prolactin-secreting adenoma or prolactinoma is the most common type of functioning pituitary 
adenoma. Pituitary adenomas are the most common type of pituitary tumor, accounting for 
one-third of all tumors.
questions.chapter_heading: Pituitary Tumours and Sheehan s Syndrome

questions.question: Question 2: What are the most common cells involved in non-functioning pituitary adenoma?
questions.explanation:
Non-functioning pituitary adenomas most commonly arise from gonadotropic cells (80%). Pituitary adenomas are classified as functioning or non-functioning based on the secretion of 
hormones. Non-functioning adenomas are usually asymptomatic in the initial stages but as the 
tumor grows larger, mass effect produces clinical manifestations such as: 73 
Sold by @itachibot • Headache • Bitemporal hemianopia • Diplopia, ptosis • Compression of pituitary stalk • Hyperprolactinemia initially - reduced dopamine release leads to loss of inhibition of lactotrophs • Hypopituitarism in later stages
questions.chapter_heading: Pituitary Tumours and Sheehan s Syndrome

questions.question:
Question 3: A 30-year-old woman with a suspected prolactinoma is planned for a brain MRI. What size 
would the tumor have to be to call it a microadenoma?
questions.explanation:
Pituitary adenomas < 10 mm are called microadenomas. Asymptomatic pituitary tumors can be discovered incidentally on imaging. They must also be 
suspected in patients with features of hormone hypersecretion or mass effect. In such cases, MRI 
with contrast is the best investigation to detect the tumor, as shown below. Levels of pituitary hormones must also be measured to rule out both hypersecretion 
and hyposecretion.
questions.chapter_heading: Pituitary Tumours and Sheehan s Syndrome

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following would not occur in a patient with a pituitary macroadenoma?

options.c: Low serum thyroxine and TSH levels

questions.explanation:
Pituitary macroadenomas do not cause pigmentation of mucous membranes as ACTH levels are 
low. In this condition, there is destruction of the pituitary gland by mass effect. This leads to 
panhypopituitarism or reduced levels of all hormones, including ACTH. Excessive pigmentation is 
only seen in cases of excess ACTH. The following hormones are deficient in panhypopituitarism: 74 
Sold by @itachibot • ACTH - Secondary adrenal insufficiency • TSH - Secondary hypothyroidism • GH - Growth failure and adult hyposomatotropism • FSH, LH - Hypogonadic hypogonadism • Prolactin - Lactation failure Adiponectin, secreted by fat cells normally increases insulin sensitivity. It is usually suppressed by 
cortisol. In panhypopituitarism, decreased cortisol levels lead to increased insulin sensitivity.
questions.chapter_heading: Pituitary Tumours and Sheehan s Syndrome

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following can occur in a patient with prolactinoma?
questions.explanation:
Superior quadrantanopia may be seen in patients with prolactinoma > 10 mm in size 
(macroadenoma). In this condition, visual field defects occur due to compression of the optic chiasm. In the initial 
stages, the pituitary tumor tends to compress the ventral portion of the optic chiasm. This causes 
a bitemporal (heteronymous) superior field defect. As the tumor grows larger, the entire optic 
chiasm gets compressed, leading to complete bitemporal hemianopia, as shown below. Damage to the optic radiation in the temporal lobe would result in homonymous superior 
quadrantanopia or pie-in-the-sky appearance.
questions.chapter_heading: Pituitary Tumours and Sheehan s Syndrome

questions.question: Question 6: What levels of prolactin are definitely suggestive of prolactinoma?
questions.explanation:
The diagnosis of a prolactinoma is highly likely when prolactin levels are > 200 g/L. The normal range of serum prolactin (PRL) is 5-20 g/L. Prolactin levels < 100 g/L can be due 
to non-functioning pituitary adenomas or non-neoplastic causes of hyperprolactinemia. MRI brain 
must be done in all patients with hyperprolactinemia. Prolactinoma are tumors arising from the lactotroph cells of the pituitary gland, they can be 
classified as microadenoma(<1cm in diameter, usually non invasive ) or 
macroadenoma(>1cm, locally invasive to adjacent structures). Clinical features include 
amenorrhea, infertility, and galactorrhea in women, impotence, loss of libido, infertility in men 
and if tumor extends beyond sella, there can be visual field defects and other mass effects. Treatment - In asymptomatic patients and those where fertility is not desired, they do not require 
treatment and can be monitored using regular PRL measurements and MRI. In symptomatic 
microadenoma cases, oral dopamine agonists (cabergoline and bromocriptine) form the main 
treatment for hyperprolactinemia and reduction of tumor volume. For macroadenoma, before 
starting dopamine agonists visual field testing is to be done, and reassess it with MRI changes 
every 6-12 month intervals until maximum reduction is achieved, in unresponsive cases consider 
surgery. 75 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Pituitary Tumours and Sheehan s Syndrome

questions.question:
Question 7: Patients with which of the following conditions do not need to be screened for pituitary 
tumors?
questions.explanation:
MEN2 syndrome is not associated with pituitary tumors. It is associated with medullary thyroid 
cancer and pheochromocytoma. The genetic syndromes associated with pituitary tumors include: • MEN1 • MEN4 • Carney complex tumors • McCune-Albright Syndrome
questions.chapter_heading: Pituitary Tumours and Sheehan s Syndrome

questions.question:
Question 8: A 56-year-old woman presented with a gradually diminishing visual field. She was found to 
have a pituitary mass and underwent trans-sphenoidal hypophysectomy. Now she has low 
levels of ACTH, TSH, FSH, and LH. Which of the following hormone supplements is not 
needed in the patient postoperatively? 70 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario describes a woman presenting with hypopituitarism following 
trans-sphenoidal resection. Mineralocorticoid supplementation is not needed postoperatively as it 
is regulated by the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system and not by ACTH. Therefore, 
mineralocorticoid levels would remain intact despite ACTH deficiency. Thyroid hormone, estradiol, and glucocorticoid supplementation are needed in this patient as 
their secretion is regulated by anterior pituitary hormones. Features of hypopituitarism include growth abnormalities in children with a growth hormone 
deficiency, insufficient levels of gonadotropins leading to menstrual irregularities, infertility in 
women and reduced sexual function, infertility and loss of secondary sexual characteristics in 
men. TSH deficiency leads to stunted growth in children and features of hypothyroidism in both 
children and adults. ACTH deficiency leads to secondary adrenal insufficiency. Polyuria and polydipsia may be seen and indicate a loss of vasopressin secretion in posterior 
pituitary lesions. The following hormones must be replaced post-hypophysectomy: Hormone Replacement Trophic hormone defic

questions.question:
Question 9: Which of the following is the most common clinical presentation in patients with 
craniopharyngiomas?
questions.explanation:
Headache is the most common presenting symptom of craniopharyngioma. Craniopharyngiomas are benign, suprasellar cystic masses. They have a bimodal distribution, 
occurring predominantly in children but also between the ages of 55 and 65 years. It can present 
with the following clinical symptoms: • Headache • Hypopituitarism • Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism • Central diabetes insipidus • Bitemporal hemianopia • Raised ICT - vomiting, papilledema, hydrocephalus
questions.chapter_heading: Pituitary Tumours and Sheehan s Syndrome

questions.question:
Question 10: A 10-year-old boy is referred for evaluation of progressively worsening headaches and visual 
field defects. An MRI brain is done and shows the following findings. Which of the following 
statements is incorrect about this condition?

options.b: Surgery is curative in most patients
options.d: Calcifications are seen in adamantinomatous type

questions.explanation:
The given MRI showing a suprasellar mass with calcifications is suggestive of a 
craniopharyngioma. Surgery is not curative in the majority of patients as the tumor is adherent to 
surrounding structures. They are benign epithelial cell-containing tumors and are of two types: • Adamantinomatous - calcifications and keratin nodules are seen • Papillary - calcifications are rare Biopsy reveals machinery or motor-oil-like fluid within the cyst that contains cholesterol 
crystals. The treatment of choice is transcranial or transsphenoidal resection. It must be followed 
by postoperative radiation to prevent recurrence.
questions.chapter_heading: Pituitary Tumours and Sheehan s Syndrome

questions.question: Question 11: Patients with which of the following conditions are not at risk for pituitary apoplexy?
questions.explanation:
Pituitary apoplexy does not occur in hyperthyroidism. It is a rare endocrine emergency which can 
occur due to haemorrhage or infarction of the pituitary gland. It may occur as a result of the 
following conditions: • Pituitary adenoma (spontaneous) • Sheehan syndrome • Acute shock • Diabetes mellitus • Hypertension • Sickle cell anemia 77 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Pituitary Tumours and Sheehan s Syndrome

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following is seen in pituitary apoplexy?
questions.explanation:
Shock is seen in pituitary apoplexy. Loss of consciousness (Option C) can also be seen but it occurs secondary to adrenal insufficiency 
and shock. Hence, shock is the most appropriate answer. Pituitary apoplexy refers to acute hemorrhagic infarction of the pituitary gland. This results in the 
compression of surrounding structures and hypopituitarism leading to acute adrenal insufficiency. 
It may be seen spontaneously in a pre-existing pituitary adenoma, post-partum (Sheehan’s 
syndrome), or be associated with hypertension, diabetes mellitus or sickle cell anemia or shock. Pituitary apoplexy is an endocrine emergency that can lead to severe hypoglycemia, hypotension, 
shock, central nervous system (CNS) hemorrhage, and death. Acute clinical manifestations 
commonly encompass intense headaches with signs of meningeal irritation, bilateral visual 
changes, ophthalmoplegia, and even cardiovascular collapse. The investigation of choice is MRI. Patients who do not exhibit overt visual impairment or altered mental status can be managed 
conservatively with high-dose glucocorticoids. Progressive visual loss, cranial nerve palsy, or 
altered mental status necessitate expeditious surgical decompression.
questions.chapter_heading: Pituitary Tumours and Sheehan s Syndrome

questions.question: Question 13: Which hormone is the first to fall in Sheehan syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Growth hormone (GH) is the first to fall in Sheehan syndrome. The hormones are affected in the 
order of GH  Prolactin  LH and FSH  ACTH  TSH Sheehan syndrome refers to postpartum pituitary necrosis following severe postpartum 
hemorrhage (PPH). During pregnancy, the pituitary gland undergoes hypertrophy with increased 
blood supply. This makes it susceptible to ischemia and infarction when there is severe 
hypovolemia. The clinical presentation depends on the amount of damage to the pituitary. • Mild - can go unnoticed for many years • Moderate - develops over months • Lactation failure • Failure to resume menses • Mild fatigue and anorexia • Severe - endocrine emergency that develops within few days • Hypotension and shock • Severe hypoglycemia • Lactation failure GH deficiency is very common in Sheehan’s syndrome because somatotrophs are located in the 
lower and lateral regions of the pituitary gland, and are most likely to be damaged by ischemic 
necrosis of the pituitary. 78 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Pituitary Tumours and Sheehan s Syndrome

questions.question:
Question 14: You are a first-year resident in the postpartum ward. During rounds, you see a 28-year-old 
woman who has been unable to breastfeed since delivery. Her baby was born by normal 
vaginal delivery that was complicated by severe postpartum hemorrhage. Her blood pressure 
is •0/50 mm Hg and her pulse is •6/min. What is the next best step in management?

options.a: It increases aquaporin expression on apical membrane
options.b: It increases urine concentration and decreases urine flow
options.c: AVP binds to V2 receptors on the serosal surface of renal tubular cells
options.d: AVP binds to V2 receptors on the luminal surface of renal tubular cells

questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of Sheehan syndrome. Corticosteroids must be 
supplemented first, as life-threatening manifestations may occur due to the sudden onset of 
adrenal insufficiency. This is followed by the replacement of other deficient pituitary hormones 
including thyroid hormone and estrogen administered with or without progesterone. 79
